channel.title: self on Tushar Chandra
channel.description: Recent content in self on Tushar Chandra

item.title: Generalized SEIR Model On Large Networks
item.description: SEIR models for epidemiology break down a population into four partitions: susceptible, exposed, infected, and recovered. This talk gives an overview of how seirsplus can be used with MLflow and hyperopt to run simulations and experiments of possible COVID-19 scenarios.

item.title: Automated Testing For Protecting Data Pipelines from Undocumented Assumptions
item.description: Data pipelines are fraught with undocumented assumptions: about column data types, nullability, acceptable values, and more. Automated unit testing often fails to catch violations of these assumptions. The speakers from Superconductive introduce Great Expectations, a library to build these assumptions into a data pipeline.

item.title: Democratizing PySpark For Mobile Game Publishing
item.description: This talk, by Ben Weber of Zynga, talks about their experiences making their PySpark environment available to everyone in their analytics function. Democratizing PySpark in this way, while not easy, helped to improve their analytics function.

item.title: Friday morning keynotes: on PyTorch and COVID
item.description: The Friday morning keynotes included a talk about PyTorch by its author Adam Paszke, and “science vs. COVID” from Amy Heineike of Covid19Primer.com.

item.title: Geospatial Analytics At Scale: Analyzing Human Movement Patterns During A Pandemic
item.description: How does Esri use Spark and GIS to analyze human movement? How do they use this insight to assess risk? This talk attempts to answer these.

item.title: Patterns And Anti-Patterns For Memorializing Data Science Project Artifacts
item.description: So you need to save your work for future data scientists; how do you do this? This talk discusses best practices for saving artifacts from data science projects.

item.title: Automated And Explainable Deep Learning For Clinical Language Understanding At Roche
item.description: How does Roche use machine learning to help understand pathology reports? This talk gives a high-level overview of their data pipeline and tech stack, including infrastructure they’ve built up to do OCR and NLP.

item.title: An Approach To Data Quality For Netflix Personalization Systems
item.description: Netflix ingests terabytes of data and billions of rows daily, and these are used for personalized recommendations both online and offline. How do they manage data quality? By lots and lots of quality checks early on.

item.title: Using Bayesian Generative Models With Apache Spark To Solve Entity Resolution Problems At Scale
item.description: Deduplication is a huge problem in many domains; this talk by two people from MavenCode discusses how they’ve used Spark-driven Bayesian generative models to solve large entity resolution problems.

item.title: Everyday Probabilistic Data Structures for Humans
item.description: When your data gets extremely large, real-time queries can become expensive and slow. Yeshwanth Vijayakumar from Adobe discusses how probabilistic data structures can help to solve these scaling problems efficiently.

item.title: Notes from the Thursday morning Spark keynotes
item.description: The morning keynotes were more Databricks-focused; topics included updates to the Databricks workspace environment, new and upcoming features in MLflow (and that it’s joining the Linux Foundation!), and demos on “responsible AI” from Microsoft.

item.title: Wednesday afternoon keynotes: racism, COVID, and politics
item.description: The afternoon keynotes were on racism in policing, data in COVID-19, and lessons from FiveThirtyEight. Dr. Phillip Goff delivered an incredible talk on what we need to invest in to support Black communities, and Nate Silver went on with what it means to think probabilistically and work together in crisis. Amazing!

item.title: How (not) to scale deep learning in 6 easy steps
item.description: The last talk of the morning session talked about common problems scaling ML and DL models: common pitfalls, things that people try too early (more hardware), and what to do instead.

item.title: Productionalizing Models through CI/CD Design with MLflow
item.description: This talk, by Mary Grace Moesta & Peter Tamisin at Databricks, dove into MLOps and productionalization of machine learning models using MLflow. How can we apply principles from CI/CD to machine learning? And how can MLflow help us to do so?

item.title: Portable Scalable Data Visualization Techniques for Apache Spark and Python Notebook-based Analytics
item.description: This talk, by Douglas Moore at Databricks, briefly discussed strategies for data visualization using Spark and different visualization libraries.

item.title: Notes from the Wednesday morning Spark keynotes
item.description: Spark + AI Summit kicked off with keynotes by Ali Ghodsi (Databricks CEO), Matei Zaharia (creator of Spark) and Brooke Wenig (Databricks machine learning lead), Reynold Xin (Spark contributor), and Vishwanath Subramanian (Starbucks director of data). I wasn’t able to listen to all of it, but this post has a few highlights.

item.title: [Paper] Measuring User Influence on Twitter: The Million Follower Fallacy
item.description: This 2010 paper recently won the ICWSM Test of Time award, so I gave it a look. One of the earliest papers studying Twitter, key findings include that followers are not a measure of engagement (but retweets and mentions are), and that influential users are influential about diverse and unrelated topics.

item.title: Mindful phone usage
item.description: I’ve been trying to use technology more mindfully, and in particular be more mindful about how I use my phone. I’m now trying to have an intention when I pick up my phone, instead of unlocking it and instinctively opening Chrome to hop on Twitter.

item.title: Network Propaganda, part 3
item.description: Part 3 of the book Network Propaganda is titled “The Usual Suspects,” and its focus is on the propaganda culprits who received sustained public attention. Chapter 7 focuses on the alt-right; chapter 8 Russian information operations; and chapter 9 Facebook and Cambridge Analytica.

item.title: Spark Summit 2020: an early look at the schedule
item.description: Spark + AI Summit is happening virtually next week, and I will be spending the second half of next week watching talks from there. I went through the schedule to make a preliminary list of the talks that sound interesting to me. And just like last year, I’ll be writing about them here.
